quiz.title: AP Physics C: Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 1, Quiz 1: Vector Calculus in Motion
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: The position of a particle is given by the vector $\mathbf{r}(t) = (t^2 + 2)\hat{i} + (5t)\hat{j}$. What is the velocity vector $\mathbf{v}(t)$ at $t = 3\text{ s}$?
A particle moves with a velocity vector $\mathbf{v}(t) = (3\cos t)\hat{i} + (3\sin t)\hat{j}$. Which of the following describes the acceleration vector $\mathbf{a}(t)$?
options: It is always parallel to the velocity.
It is always perpendicular to the velocity.
It is constant in both magnitude and direction.
It is zero because the speed is constant.
questions.explanation: $\mathbf{a}(t) = \frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt} = (-3\sin t)\hat{i} + (3\cos t)\hat{j}$. Compute $\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{a} = (3\cos t)(-3\sin t) + (3\sin t)(3\cos t) = -9\sin t\cos t + 9\sin t\cos t = 0$. Zero dot product means perpendicular.

questions.question: If a particleâ€™s position is defined by $x(t) = \sin(2t)$ and $y(t) = \cos(2t)$, what is the magnitude of its velocity (speed) at any time $t$?
An object starts from rest at the origin. Its acceleration vector is $\mathbf{a}(t) = (2)\hat{i} + (6t)\hat{j}$. What is its position vector $\mathbf{r}(t)$ at $t = 1\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Integrate acceleration: $\mathbf{v}(t) = \int \mathbf{a}\, dt = 2t\hat{i} + 3t^2\hat{j} + \mathbf{C}$. Since starting from rest, $\mathbf{v}(0)=0$, so $\mathbf{C}=0$. Integrate velocity: $\mathbf{r}(t) = \int \mathbf{v}\, dt = t^2\hat{i} + t^3\hat{j} + \mathbf{C'}$. Starting at origin, $\mathbf{r}(0)=0$, so $\mathbf{C'}=0$. At $t=1$: $\mathbf{r} = 1\hat{i} + 1\hat{j}$.

questions.question: For a particle moving along a path $\mathbf{r}(t)$, the unit tangent vector $\mathbf{\hat{T}}$ points in the direction of:
questions.explanation: The unit tangent vector is defined as $\mathbf{\hat{T}} = \frac{\mathbf{v}}{|\mathbf{v}|}$, where $\mathbf{v}$ is the velocity vector. Therefore, it always points in the instantaneous direction of motion, tangent to the path.

questions.question: A particle moves such that its radial position is $r = t^2$ and its angular position is $\theta = 2t$. The radial component of its velocity ($v_r = \dot{r}$) at $t = 2\text{ s}$ is:
questions.explanation: The radial component of velocity in polar coordinates is $v_r = \frac{dr}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(t^2) = 2t$. At $t=2\text{ s}$: $v_r = 2(2) = 4$.

questions.question: Car A moves with $\mathbf{v}_A = 10\hat{i} + 5\hat{j}$. Car B moves with $\mathbf{v}_B = 2\hat{i} - 1\hat{j}$. The velocity of Car A relative to Car B ($\mathbf{v}_{A/B}$) is:
At $t = 1\text{ s}$, a particle has velocity components $v_x = 4\text{ m/s}$ and $v_y = 4\text{ m/s}$. The angle of the velocity vector with respect to the positive x-axis is:
questions.explanation: The direction of the velocity vector is given by $\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{v_y}{v_x}\right) = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{4}{4}\right) = \tan^{-1}(1) = 45^\circ$.

questions.question: A position vector is defined as $\mathbf{r}(t) = (t^3 - 3t)\hat{i} + (4t^2)\hat{j}$. At what time $t$ is the x-component of acceleration zero?
questions.explanation: $x(t) = t^3 - 3t \Rightarrow v_x(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 3t^2 - 3 \Rightarrow a_x(t) = \frac{dv_x}{dt} = 6t$. Set $a_x = 0$: $6t = 0 \Rightarrow t = 0\text{ s}$.

questions.question: If $\mathbf{a}(t) = 3\hat{i} - 4t\hat{j}$, what is the magnitude of the acceleration at $t = 1\text{ s}$?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered vector calculus as applied to motion, including differentiation, integration, polar components, and relative motion.
scoreMessages.70: Very strong performance. Review: perpendicular acceleration in uniform circular motion, integrating from acceleration to position, and polar coordinate velocity components.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation. Focus on: differentiating position vectors, calculating speed from components, performing vector integrals, and finding relative velocities.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the basics: $\mathbf{v} = d\mathbf{r}/dt$, $\mathbf{a} = d\mathbf{v}/dt$, and practice vector addition/subtraction for relative motion.
